2007-08-07.snippet: LAW ON STRANDED PASSENGERS Airlines operating in New York would be required to provide fresh air, toilet-waste removal, drinking water and snacks to passengers on an airplane that has left the gate and remains parked on an airport apron under a ne...
2007-08-07.lead_paragraph: LAW ON STRANDED PASSENGERS Airlines operating in New York would be required to provide fresh air, toilet-waste removal, drinking water and snacks to passengers on an airplane that has left the gate and remains parked on an airport apron under a new state law signed by Gov. Eliot Spitzer last week. The legislation, originally drafted by a state assemblyman from Queens, Michael N. Gianaris, would take effect Jan. 1, although the airline industry has said it is considering a legal challenge. The Airline Passengers Bill of Rights came in response to instances of passengers being stranded for hours on parked planes, with inadequate ventilation and food and deteriorating hygienic conditions. On Feb. 14, for example, thousands of JetBlue passengers sat on parked planes during a snow and ice storm for as long as 10 hours at Kennedy International Airport.

2007-08-14.snippet: VERY LATE TO THE GATE As domestic air traffic continues to be plagued this summer by the worst delays on record, FlightStats.com compiled data on individual airlines’ performances in July compared with those in the month a year earlier. Amer...
2007-08-14.lead_paragraph: VERY LATE TO THE GATE As domestic air traffic continues to be plagued this summer by the worst delays on record, FlightStats.com compiled data on individual airlines’ performances in July compared with those in the month a year earlier. American Airlines had by far the largest number of flights arriving 45 or more minutes late: 12,302 (17.9 percent of its 68,366 flights in July). Next among major carriers in “excessive arrival delays” were Continental (15.9 percent of 37,386 flights); Delta (15.3 percent of 50,842 flights); US Airways (15.3 percent of 29,476 flights); United (14.2 percent of 52,097 flights); and Northwest (10.1 percent of 42,931 flights). But Northwest had by far the highest flight-cancellation rate: 1,895, or 4.4 percent of its flights.

2007-08-21.snippet: FIRST COMMERCIAL A380 FLIGHT Singapore Airlines will begin auctioning seats on eBay next Monday for the first commercial flight of the A380 superjumbo jet, scheduled for Oct. 25 from Singapore to Sydney. Proceeds will go to charity. Singapore will...
2007-08-21.lead_paragraph: FIRST COMMERCIAL A380 FLIGHT Singapore Airlines will begin auctioning seats on eBay next Monday for the first commercial flight of the A380 superjumbo jet, scheduled for Oct. 25 from Singapore to Sydney. Proceeds will go to charity. Singapore will be the first airline to take delivery of the long-delayed Airbus double-decker aircraft, which is certified to hold 853 passengers in a single-class configuration. Singapore said it would configure its A380s with 471 seats in three classes: economy, business and what the airline calls “a class beyond first.” No United States carriers have ordered the planes, but international airlines that are buying A380s have all said they intend to fly them with no more than about 550 passengers in economy and premium cabins. Singapore, which has ordered 19 A380s, has not yet unveiled its new first-class cabins for the jets, but is expected to do so soon. A380s have previously flown passengers on noncommercial demonstration flights.
